data.title: [python] Replace TextMate for Python syntax highlighting

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
VS Code's syntax highlighting for Python is [broken in a few ways](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/1467).

VS Code currently uses [TextMate's Python bundle](https://github.com/textmate/python.tmbundle) for syntax highlighting. The problem is that this project seems to be unmaintained. The last commit was from mid-2014.

We should replace this with a project that is more up-to-date and actively maintained. [PythonImproved](https://github.com/MattDMo/PythonImproved) seems to fit the bill, though I haven't used it yet. I've asked the maintainers of that project about [compatibility with VS Code](https://github.com/MattDMo/PythonImproved/issues/57).

If anyone has other suggestions for a better tokenizer for Python, please speak up.

data.title: VS Code window does not open on Primary screen if it's set to an external display

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I recently fresh installed VS Code. I use my laptop as a desktop PC with Windows 10 and I have a connected external display.
The display projection setting is set to "Second screen only".
At the first launch the VS Code's icon has been appeared on the taskbar but nothing happened.
Hovering over the icon shows that the window is actually opened and VS Code is running.
However, it is positioned to the laptop screen (which is not used/turned off).
Workaround: set Project (Win+P) to Extend, then back to Second screen only.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1768446/12537596/14d23e22-c2c3-11e5-9880-ba40a78434e0.png)

data.body:

data.title: Multi-cursor pastes in reverse order
[html] attribute on separate line formatting
data.body:
HTML Formatting ideally should have a feature to separate attributes on new lines when using `format code`.

e.g.

``` html
<my-hero-list [heroes]="heroes" (selectHero)="onSelect($event)" class="nav"></my-hero-list>
```

When using format code should be formatted as:

``` html
<my-hero-list [heroes]="heroes" 
    (selectHero)="onSelect($event)"
    class="nav">
</my-hero-list>
```

data.title: ESLint - Stylish reporter now reports absolute paths.
data.body:
Extracted from comment from @felixfbecker in issue #1420.

I have the exact same problem with eslint:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10532611/12521660/30167838-c14c-11e5-8eef-b7a5d2004935.png)

tasks.json:

``` json
{
  "version": "0.1.0",
  "command": "npm",
  "args": ["--loglevel", "silent", "run"],
  "isShellCommand": true,
  "showOutput": "silent",
  "tasks": [
    {
      "taskName": "lint",
      "problemMatcher": "$eslint-stylish"
    }
  ]
}
```

Setting the problem matcher with fileLocation: absolute works, but imo this should not be needed. I have the latest eslint version installed so $eslint-stylish should set this automatically.

data.title: Visual Studio Code finds TypeScript errors in the TypeScript source itself

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
1) `git clone https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript.git`
2) `Code TypeScript &`
3) Code reports 41 errors.

Example code it doesn't like is the `"string"` in the below.
Perhaps it is a TypeScript version issue?
How can I update the TypeScript version?

``` js
    /* @internal */
    export interface CommandLineOptionBase {
        name: string;
        type: "string" | "number" | "boolean" | Map<number>;    // a value of a primitive type, or an object literal mapping named values to actual values
        isFilePath?: boolean;                                   // True if option value is a path or fileName
        shortName?: string;                                     // A short mnemonic for convenience - for instance, 'h' can be used in place of 'help'
        description?: DiagnosticMessage;                        // The message describing what the command line switch does
        paramType?: DiagnosticMessage;                          // The name to be used for a non-boolean option's parameter
        experimental?: boolean;
    }
```

Code version:

```
Version 0.10.6
Commit a80232bbcfe8a5cdad1ebc98638673d9dcb02458
Date 2015-12-19T11:26:42.359Z
Shell 0.34.5
Renderer 45.0.2454.85
Node 4.1.1
```

data.title: Installation: No executable and windows.h not found error
data.body:
I'm using Ubuntu, nvm and node 5.3.0. I followed the build instructions carefully and after executing `npm.sh install`, I successfully built and ran VSCode via `scripts/code.sh`. The problem is that this script is meant for development mode, and I'd like to run VSCode in production mode.

I don't find any executable named `Code` anywhere in node's bin or VSCode's source directory.

Also, during the installation procedure the `windows-mutex` package attempts to install and of course fails (I'm on Ubuntu):

```
  CXX(target) Release/obj.target/CreateMutex/src/main.o
../src/main.cc:2:21: fatal error: windows.h: No such file or directory
 #include <windows.h>
                     ^
compilation terminated.
CreateMutex.target.mk:91: recipe for target 'Release/obj.target/CreateMutex/src/main.o' failed
```

Why can't I see VSCode's executable? Could this error be part of the problem?

data.title: JavaScript IntelliSense Problem
data.body:
Windows 7 / VS Code 0.10.6

A simple JavaScript project folder with two files:  

`crt.js` file is used as the source of intellisense function.

```
var foo = {};
foo.Version = '1.0';

var bar = {
  Version: '1.0';
}
```

`main.js` file use the variables defined in `crt.js` file:

```
foo.(no suggestion shows here)
bar.(shows Version as suggestion)
```

Can we have the foo show suggestions as bar?

Andrew

data.title: Improved support for remote node debugging
data.body:
- [x] win @SofianHn 
- [x] mac @joaomoreno  
- [x] linux @aeschli 

The followings fixes and features enable the VSCode node debugger to better support remote debugging (which includes debugging into a docker container).
- A remote debug session will no longer terminate after 3 seconds (a watchdog timer was tracking the **local** existence of the node process which does not really make sense in the remote case...)
- the `attach` launch config got the `address` attribute back. So it is again possible to specify a TCP/IP address. Please note that remote debugging is only supported on recent versions of node.
- the `attach` launch config now supports a `localRoot` and a `remoteRoot` attribute that can be used to map paths between a local VS Code project and a (remote) node folder. This works even locally on the same system or across different operating systems.

Verify that you can remote debug node apps. Here are some examples for what scenarios to test:
- debug a node app running inside a docker container (e.g. Windows -> Docker).
- debug a node app running inside a virtual machine (e.g. Mac -> Window, Mac -> Linux).
- debug a node app running locally from a different folder than the VS Code workspace.
- debug a node app running on a real remote system.

data.title: Find is not available in Markdown Preview mode
data.body:
# Find is not available in Markdown Preview mode
## Feature Request?

This may be a feature request, but I would like to search my Markdown in Preview Mode.

Currently this action is not available.
## Repro Steps
1. Create a markdown document
2. Go to Preview Mode
3. Try a Find - Ctrl-F (Cmd-F) 
4. Find is not available.

data.title: Source maps with inlined source
data.body:
- [x] win @SofianHn 
- [x] mac @joaomoreno 
- [x] linux @aeschli 

Node debugging now supports source maps with "inlined source" (Please find the definition of "inlined source" vs. "inlined source maps" below).

Here is the strategy in what situations VSCode will use "inlined source":
VSCode always tries to locate the source on disk first. If it cannot find the source (e.g. because there is none or because the paths in the source maps are broken), VSCode will use the "inlined source" if available. If there is no inlined source, VSCode will fall back to stream the file contents from node itself.

If the editor contents is not loaded by VSCode from the file system but comes from the debug adapter, the editor will be in readonly mode and the "origin" of the editor contents is shown in the editor title:

![2016-01-22 16-24-31](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/12514672/cadac9a0-c124-11e5-9838-b09bdf57c45a.png)

**Test:** For your favourite project create source maps with inlined source.
- verify that VSCode uses the strategy from above for showing the source
- verify that you can step through inlined source
- verify that breakpoints can be set in inlined source and that they are persisted
- combine inlined source and inlined source maps and verify that still everything works.

**Note:** "inlined source" and "inlined source maps" are orthogonal features (and VSCode supports both either alone or in combination):
- _inlined source maps:_ the contents of the source map does not live in a file but is a data url at the end of the generated file
- _inlined source:_ the contents of the original source file does not live in a file but is included in the source map.

data.title: Allow to select + copy all in debug console
data.body: Common question for resolving issues with debug adapters is "paste the logs". This is currently easier said then done because you cannot press Ctrl+A in the debug console and you can only select text that is currently visible. It would also be nice to be able to toggle line wrap.
